docs.lead_paragraph: Sherry Markovitz Monique Knowlton Gallery 568 Broadway, at Prince Street SoHo Through Jan. 24 The word ''adornment'' takes on new dimension in the work of Sherry Markovitz, a Seattle artist whose sculptures of dolls, animal trophies and abstract forms are exquisitely patterned with tiny hand-strung beads, baubles, feathers, flowers and other minutiae. So skillfully is this accomplished that in an interesting reversal, the sculptures themselves seem the very essence of their showy yet subtle and intricate surfaces.
docs.abstract: Grace Glueck reviews exhibit of sculptures of Sherry Markovitz, at Monique Knowlton Gallery (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The mother of Justina Morales was sentenced to five years on probation yesterday after earlier admitting she had agreed with her boyfriend's determination to kill her daughter. But the judge imposed an unusual condition: if the woman, Denise Solero, becomes pregnant again, she must inform the Probation Department so a court can determine if she is fit to care for the child. A Probation Department spokesman, Jack F. Ryan, termed the pregnancy-reporting requirement imposed on Denise Solero, 30, exceptional as part of a probation sentence in New York City.
docs.abstract: Denise Solero, who admitted helping her boyfriend kill her 8-year-old daughter, Justina Morales, is sentenced to five years on probation by Acting Justice Joseph F Bruno; judge notes that Solero fulfilled her plea-deal obligation by testifying against boyfriend, Luis Santiago; judge imposes unusual condition: if Solero becomes pregnant again, she must inform Probation Dept so court can determine if she is fit to care for child; prosecutors had portrayed Solero as battered woman; they said need for vital testimony against Santiago necessitated probation deal (M)
